titleInfo.title: 1861-1865 The Tar Heels Roll of Honor

originInfo.publisher: Holladay Studio, Durham, N.C.
North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

mods.note: 42905 Commercialchrome.
Notation on back reads, "942, Date: Oct 13 '15, Job: Holladay Studio, Cus: Gen J.H. Carr, Durham, N.C."

Drawing of a foot with tar on the heel, honoring North Carolina's soldiers in the Civil War. The front of the card reads, "1861-1865, the Tar Heels Roll of Honor. North Carolina, with a male population (military age) of 115,000 furnished 127,000 Confederate Soldiers Lost 40,735 of her brave sons, double the loss of any other state with 5,000 to spare. First at Bethel, Foremost at Gettysburg, the last at Appomattox. 'God Bless North Carolina' [signed] R.E. Lee." The bottom of the card includes the state toast, "Here's the the land of the Long Leaf Pine, The Summer land where the Sun doth Shine, Where the Weat grow Strong and the Strong grow Great, Here's to North Carolina, the good Old Tar Heel State."
mods.identifier: "1861-1865 The Tar Heels Roll of Honor," in Durwood Barbour Collection of North Carolina Postcards (P077), North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, UNC-Chapel Hill
mods.note: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

Message on back of card: "Hope that you are enjoying just such delightful weather as we are. And that you are not having any more 'floods.' Had such a nice letter from Rosa recently. originInfo.publisher: Service Merchandise Co., Wilmington, N.C.
North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

mods.note: Wilmington, North Carolina's Port City, has been transformed into one of the most active defense centers of the country, with the establishment nearby of Camp Davis, the home of the Anti-Aircraft Artillery School. The North Carolina Ship-Building Company is also located here and operates a nine-way yard for the building of steel cargo ships, for the Government. Front Street is the principal business throughfare and represents a scene of commercial activity at all times. Service Merchandise Co., Wilmington, N.C. Genuine Curteich-Chicago "C.T. Art-Colortone" Post Card (Reg. U.S. Pat. Off.) 3B-H400.

View of downton Wilmington. There are many cars on the street and several people on the sidewalks. McLellan's store is visible at left, and on the right is the Bailey Theater, which is showing "Casablanca." The card is numbered W-8.

Nannie had circle meeting at her house yesterday with 8 present. The Fair is going on this week. See what you're missing? Ha. Ha. We're going to Reidsville to-morrow. Will miss you. Love -- Ida R." Addressed to "Miss Ruth Scott, Temple University Hospital, Philadelphia, Pa." Address corrected to "Spring Garden St., Grennsboro, North Carolina." Postmarked 9 October 1939.
View of a grocery store advertising "Fresh Meats" and "Fancy Groceries." There are displays of produce and canned goods in the front windows.

originInfo.publisher: North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

mods.note: Message on back of card: "Charlotte N.C., Feb. 20, 1918. Dear Mother, Just a few words to let you know that I am getting along fine. I was also glad to hear that you and all the family were feeling fine. Mother I tell you that I am in a good Co. Last Sunday we had a great time. Last night I was with the Jewell boys. They told me that they were going to write to Fred. I would like to have Fred with me but I guess that he is in a good Co. The address that is on this card is now my address. Your Son, Pr. M.J. Daignault, Co. E 1st Headquarters Reg., Camp Greene, Charlotte N.C. Kiss X X X X" There is no stamp or postmark.

titleInfo.title: Old Phifer Home, Charlotte, N.C.

originInfo.publisher: Asheville Post Card Co., Asheville, N.C.
North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

mods.note: Phifer Home. The home of Mr. W.F. Phifer, Charlotte, N.C., where the full Confederate Cabinet met for the last time, on April 26th, 1865. The cause of its meeting there was the fact that Mr. Trenholm, Secretary and Treasurer, was ill and confined to bed. There the immediate flight of President Davis was decided upon and the final good-byes said to the two Cabinet Officers who remained in Charlotte -- Secretary Trenholm and Attorney General George Davis. This house is owned now by Colonel W.E. Holt. Published by Asheville Post Card Co., Asheville, N.C. Commercialchrome.
View of the exterior of an old brick house. Several people stand in front of the house. The card is numbered 45976.
mods.identifier: "Old Phifer Home, Charlotte, N.C.," in Durwood Barbour Collection of North Carolina Postcards (P077), North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, UNC-Chapel Hill

mods.note: CAROLINA BEACH. This is the kind of resort which offers everything dear to the hearts of the vacationist; a batching strand which stretches into the distant haze; spacious hotels, large guest houses and cottages, and hundreds of private homes. It is a haven to the young high school and college crowd. With two long piers jutting out to the very breeding grounds of the game sea denizens, it is "fishing home" to countless thousands of sportsmen all over the South. Says: Charlotte, North Carolina is a city of opportunity and a thriving metropolis of more than 100,000 people. Located in the heart of the Southeast's most rapidly expanding commercial area, it is an industrial and manufacturing city, and a rich retail trading center. It affords unusual opportunities for new industries on account of its fine transportation facilities, its central location, and its splendid electric power service. For further information, write Charlotte Chamber of Commerce, Charlotte, N.C."

titleInfo.title: Diocesan Missionary Fathers, 701 S. Main Street, Wake Forest, North Carolina

originInfo.publisher: Curt Teich & Co., Chicago, Ill.
North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

mods.note: The Madonna of the Highways Trailer Chapel is a motor chapel owned by the Catholic Diocese of Raleigh, North Carolina, and operated throughout the state by the Diocesan Missionary Fathers. Designed by Geo. F. Chaplin, it was built in 1948 and paid for by generous friends of the missions. It has an altar which can be used interiorly or exteriorly, a confessional, stations of the cross, and all church equipment besides living quarters and accommodations for two priests. A public address system, radio and victrola equipment as well as motion picture projector help the missionaries bring to Catholics and non-Catholics in rural areas and in small towns, the Word of God. It was dedicated by Bishop Waters at Wilmington, N.C., in May 1948. You are invited to visit the Chapel on the road, or at our home in Wake Forest, N.C. Genuine Curteich-Chicago "C.T. Art-Colortone" Post Card (Reg. U.S. Pat. Off.) 4B-H179.
The larger image is of a car with a trailer parked on the side of a street. The smaller image shows a priest giving a sermon from the back of a trailer.

titleInfo.title: Taft Welcome Arch Wilmington N.C.

originInfo.publisher: North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

mods.note: Copyright by U.C. Ellis 1909.

Message on back of card: "I was not here when Taft was here but will send you some cards to let you see how they had decorated for him. Hope these few will reach and find you enjoying life fine. What has become of cousin Tim I haven't heard a word from him in a long time guess he is getting ready to get married. Tell him to let me know and I will send him a congratulation card. Will stop for this time with many good wishes. As ever, Jessie." There is no address, postmark, or stamp on the back of the card.
View of an elaborately decorated street and an arch bearing the phrase "Welcome to the 'Land of the Long Leaf Pine'."
mods.identifier: "Taft Welcome Arch Wilmington N.C.," in Durwood Barbour Collection of North Carolina Postcards (P077), North Carolina Collection Photographic Archives, Wilson Library, UNC-Chapel Hill
